Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: The clock on my desk blinked 4:00 PM, and my heart thudded with anxiety. Only an hour left in my shift, and I was still three sales short of my weekly target. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We need you to hit your numbers this week.” I dialed another number, rehearsing my pitch, but my mind kept drifting to the evening ahead. Tonight was the puja at my uncle’s house—a family ceremony I couldn’t miss. My mother had called twice already, reminding me to come straight home, change into my kurta, and help with the preparations. The thought of disappointing my family, of missing the prayers and the laughter, twisted in my chest. Yet, the pressure to perform at work was just as heavy. If I left now, I’d fall short of my target, risking my bonus and maybe even my job. If I stayed, I’d be late for the ceremony, letting down my family and my faith. My hands trembled as I stared at the phone, torn between two worlds, each demanding more than I felt I could give.
